title: Boris Johnson attacks Heathrow expansion again
text:
Boris Johnson attacks Heathrow expansion again 3 August 2015 Save 
Mayor of London Boris Johnson has again slammed the “shameful and above all short-termist decision” that could see Heathrow given a third runway 
Writing in his weekly column in The Telegraph , he argued that any expansion would reduce domestic connections while offering limited growth on the international side. 
And while he admitted Sir Howard Davies was right to recommend that the UK needs a hub airport in the Airports Commission report, he argued that only his pet project, a newly built airport in the Thames estuary, could deliver the relief required. 
Johnson wrote: “Heathrow used to be number one, but for about 20 years it has been stuck on 180 routes, while Paris, Frankfurt, Amsterdam now serve 250 or more. 
“The whole objective of expanding Heathrow was, in theory, to answer this basic question, so it is amazing to find that the Davies solution fails the very test he sets – failing to connect us abroad, and even at home.” 
He argued that the number of UK connections to the airport would drop from seven to four while only seven additional long-haul routes would be available by 2030. 
Johnson added that traffic would be so bad that a new congestion charge would be required in west London while Davies’s proposed partial ban on night flights would reduce connections to Hong Kong, Singapore and China. 
He said the ban would also deter low-cost carriers and argued that the night-flight ban would increase the number of nocturnal noise victims by 33%. 
He also questioned how long the ban would remain in place as well as any ban on building a fourth new runway at the facility, as has been proposed. 
Johnson said the additional runway could cost more than £40 billion, adding: “And the environmental damage is massive – another 250,000 people afflicted by noise pollution, taking the total to one million. 
“No other society is contemplating such a step backwards.” 
Instead, he again mooted his own plan for the four-runway hub to the east of the city, adding: “The GDP growth unleashed would dwarf Heathrow, with 50% more routes overall, double the number of domestic routes, to say nothing of the huge scope for much-needed housing and regeneration. 
“This is the time to ignore the pleas of the largely foreign owners of Heathrow, and to back a solution that is better for hundreds of thousands of local people, better for the economy, and better for British business as well.” Readers' comments (1) race welch | Mon, 3 Aug 2015 3:01 pm
